stream_context.summary: Kaze integrates a major visual rework of Course 1 created by graphics artist Biobak. The stream focuses on fixing the resulting rendering order bugs, implementing new actor models and effects like a dynamic sun flare, benchmarking performance, and debugging animation and collision issues in preparation for a future demo release.

development_findings.summary: Kaze spent a significant portion of the stream fixing complex rendering order issues in the newly imported Course 1, manually sorting mesh elements to ensure they display correctly.
development_findings.quote: Yeah, you can tell the drawing order here is pretty fucked.

development_findings.summary: Kaze revealed he custom-programmed jiggle physics for Mario's nose using a 'physics bone' that runs pendulum calculations, rather than using a standard animation.
development_findings.quote: It is a genuine physics bone I added to Mario... this is hyper-optimized. If you make one change to this, it's just gonna crash.

development_findings.summary: Kaze conducted performance benchmarks after importing Biobak's rework, noting a significant improvement in graphics processing time, demonstrating the team's focus on optimization.
development_findings.quote: GFX 19.10, oh my god, that is improved a lot.

development_findings.summary: A disagreement over the level's theme or name was mentioned, with Kaze asserting its identity as a 'paper crop' level against another suggestion.
development_findings.quote: The level is the paper crop level. We can't name the level after three blocks of geometry in it.

development_findings.summary: The project is approaching the 64MB ROM size limit, a significant milestone that aligns with Kaze's goal of keeping the game within authentic N64 cartridge constraints.
Kaze implemented a rotating sun flare effect inspired by Diddy Kong Racing by manipulating UV coordinates in code, opting for this method over more performance-intensive techniques.
The Goomba King boss fight is planned for a redesign, specifically focusing on changing his current movement patterns.

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds a strong philosophical belief that exceeding the original 64MB cartridge limit is against the spirit of N64 development, even if technically feasible on modern hardware.
context_findings.quote: But if you go over 64 MB, are you really still making an N64 game? It just feels like cheating to me.

context_findings.summary: Kaze clarifies that while he earns some money from the project, it is not his primary source of income and is significantly less than his normal job.
context_findings.quote: Modding makes me some amount of money through YouTube and Patreon. But it's not even half of what my normal job makes.

context_findings.summary: Kaze states his primary motivation for streaming is personal enjoyment and receiving live feedback, not to be a professional content creator.
context_findings.quote: You need to realize my streams is like minimum effort. Really I just stream because I want to stream and because I like having people be able to give me feedback on this.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is considering creating a YouTube series analyzing his own game's levels to articulate his design choices and gain new insights from the process and community feedback.
context_findings.quote: I'm going to think about why it is worth playing every individual course in RTYI. And I think while doing this series, I might realize important things.

context_findings.summary: Kaze jokes about a potential personal brand centered on a cynical view of modern games, positioning his project as an attempt to create 'the first good video game'.
context_findings.quote: I hate video games, which is why I'm trying to make a good one, because I think all of the ones are bad.

biobak.summary: Kaze highlights a key challenge in their workflow: Biobak creates assets in modern 3D software, and Kaze must then adapt them to overcome the N64's technical limitations, which Biobak isn't expected to know.
biobak.quote: This Biobak is not modeling directly on the N64, he's not gonna know what's going on. He doesn't know what's going to break and what won't.

biobak.summary: Kaze had to modify Biobak's new Goomba model because its use of billboarded elements was incompatible with the engine's specific requirements, demonstrating the need for technical adjustments to artistic assets.
biobak.quote: I respect the attempt, Biobak, but I have to change it.

biobak.summary: Biobak completed a major visual rework of Course 1, providing updated models for numerous actors including the Goomba King, Bouncy Flower, and Rabbits.
Biobak made specific creative requests for Course 1, such as implementing an 'infinitely far background' and a dynamic, rotating sun flare effect.

badub.summary: Badub has composed new music for the game, including a track for the grass area that features dynamic versions for different biomes.
badub.quote: What I forgot to mention is, this song has versions for every biome. Isn't that cool?

badub.summary: The music system is designed to support Badub's dynamic tracks by smoothly transitioning between musical elements based on the player's location in the level.
badub.quote: It will smoothly fade mini-channels in and out. That's always fitting.

zeina.summary: Kaze makes a playful, joking comment about Zeina's (Lilaa's) coding style influencing his own, offering a small glimpse into their personal and professional dynamic.
zeina.quote: Lena is evil and she makes lowercase variables and that's why I'm forced into making lowercase variables too. I'm just a girl in a man's world. True.

key_stories.title: Fixing the Course 1 Rendering Order
key_stories.summary: Kaze integrated a major visual update for Course 1 from Biobak, but it introduced severe rendering order bugs. He undertook a meticulous and frustrating process of manually re-sorting all the level's graphical elements to make them compatible with the N64's rendering pipeline, eventually succeeding and expressing great satisfaction with the final look.
key_stories.challenge: After importing Biobak's detailed visual rework for Course 1, numerous graphical elements were rendering in the wrong order, causing objects like trees and background hills to incorrectly draw over each other.
key_stories.process: Kaze systematically analyzed the level's geometry, deciding which elements could be moved to the non-transparent 'layout 0' for efficiency. He then had to fight with Blender's inconsistent sorting methods, eventually finding a combination of sorting by distance and then by material that correctly ordered the transparent elements for the N64 engine.
key_stories.outcome: After a lengthy process of trial and error, Kaze successfully sorted the geometry, fixing the rendering bugs. The result was a visually correct and aesthetically pleasing level, which he was very excited about.
key_stories.key_quote: I think this needs to render before the thing above. Oh, this is difficult.

key_stories.title: Debugging the New Goomba Models
key_stories.summary: When integrating Biobak's updated Goomba models, Kaze discovered they were broken in-game due to a technical incompatibility with the engine's billboard system. This forced Kaze to debug and rework parts of the artist's model to make it functional, highlighting the iterative technical adaptation required in their workflow.
key_stories.challenge: Biobak's new, higher-quality Goomba models did not work correctly when imported into the game. They had scaling issues, clipped through the floor, and their animations were broken, particularly for billboarded elements like the shine on the crown.
key_stories.process: Kaze reviewed the imported model in his toolset and compared it to the in-game behavior. He realized the billboarded part of the model was not parented correctly for an engine that assumes billboarded objects are spherical. He had to manually adjust the model's hierarchy and properties to better align with the engine's constraints.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze diagnosed the problem as an incompatibility between the model's armature and the engine's specific, limited handling of billboard bones. While he made progress in fixing the core issues, the animations were still not perfect by the stream's end, and he added fixing them to his to-do list.
key_stories.key_quote: I respect the attempt, Biobak, but I have to change it.

key_stories.title: Implementing the Rotating Sun Flare
key_stories.summary: Tasked with creating a dynamic sun flare, Kaze chose a performance-conscious approach by manipulating UVs in code rather than rotating the texture plane. Through a process of coding, debugging visual artifacts, and fine-tuning, he successfully implemented the complex visual effect requested by Biobak.
key_stories.challenge: Biobak requested a dynamic sun flare effect that would rotate as the player moves the camera, similar to an effect in Diddy Kong Racing, which needed to be implemented from scratch.
key_stories.process: Kaze dismissed a more straightforward but computationally expensive method. Instead, he wrote custom code to manipulate the texture's UV coordinates based on the camera's angle. He then had to debug issues related to texture clamping and mirroring to prevent visual artifacts, and fine-tune the rotation speed and influence to achieve the desired look.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully created the effect, which he was very pleased with. The final implementation features a sun that appears to rotate and blind the player when they look towards it, adding significant visual flair to the level.
key_stories.key_quote: That's so expensive! I'm not rotating a whole texture plane.
